pathway.statement: Pathway scope, required tests~warnings, and exclusions
pathway.warning: There are no warnings for this UpToDate Pathway
pathway.exclusions:
This ICG is not appropriate for patients with any of the following exclusions:
  • Prior treatment for H. pylori
  • Age <18 years
  • Pregnant or breastfeeding

questions.question: Is this UpToDate Pathway appropriate for this patient?

options.label: Yes
No

questions.content:
Scope

This UpToDate Pathway will help guide clinicians in selecting therapy for an adult with Helicobacter pylori infection who has not previously been treated. Several guidelines address the management of H. pylori. The recommendations in this ICG generally represent the recommendations from the Toronto guidelines.

Last updated 12/12/2016

Required Tests

No test results other than an initial test that is positive for H. pylori infection are needed in order to complete this ICG.
questions.warning: This UpToDate Pathway is not appropriate for this patient because one or more exclusions are present. For additional information on the approach to patients not covered by this UpToDate Pathway, please refer to Related UpToDate Content. Close the browser tab to exit the UpToDate Pathway
questions.warningMessage: If any alarm symptoms are present the patient should undergo upper endoscopy for further evaluation in addition to receiving treatment for H. pylori. Alarm symptoms include anemia, early satiety, unexplained weight loss, dysphagia, odynophagia, recurrent vomiting, a family history of gastrointestinal cancer, and previous esophagogastric malignancy.
questions.exclusions: This ICG is not appropriate for patients with any of the following exclusions:

options.label: Yes
No

questions.content:
Risk factors for antibiotic resistance include:
  • Metronidazole use in the last three months
  • Macrolide (eg, clarithromycin, azithromycin, or erythromycin) use in the last three months
  • Residence in an area where H. pylori resistance to clarithromycin is ≥15% or where eradication rates with triple therapy are ≤85% 
In the United States, given the limited information on antimicrobial resistance rates, we generally assume clarithromycin resistance rates are ≥15% unless local data indicate otherwise.

Does the patient have risk factors for antibiotic resistance?

pathway.statement: Treat with quadruple therapy~and confirm eradication

questions.question: Choose a treatment approach

options.label: Order medications individually

addSummary.value: A PPI, bismuth, a tetracycline derivative, and metronidazole will be used

options.label: Order a proton pump inhibitor plus a combination pill (Pylera)
Approach other than the options provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

addSummary.value: Approach other than the options provided

questions.content:
Quadruple therapy for 14 days is appropriate for this patient. (Additional information)

Quadruple therapy can be administered by providing each agent individually or by providing a PPI plus a combination pill (Pylera), which combines bismuth and the two antibiotics into a single pill. Combination pills may improve adherence, but may also be more expensive.

Quadruple therapy includes:
  • A proton pump inhibitor (PPI)
  • Bismuth
  • A tetracycline derivative
  • Metronidazole
questions.addInfoContent:
• Patients should be informed that adherence to treatment is a critical factor in determining the success of eradication therapy. 
  • Because the regimen includes metronidazole, strict alcohol avoidance should be advised.

The drug doses given generally represent the doses that are suggested for patients who do not require dose adjustments due to factors such as comorbid illnesses, organ dysfunction, drug interactions, or other reasons. In addition, some of the medications used in this UpToDate Pathway should not be used concurrently with other medications because of drug interactions, so the interacting medication may need to be held during therapy or an alternative antibiotic regimen chosen (refer to UpToDate content for more details on alternative regimens). Consult a clinical drug reference, appropriate UpToDate topic reviews, and/or other resources to confirm the appropriate dosing for a given patient.

options.label: Esomeprazole 40 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Esomeprazole 20 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Lansoprazole 30 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Omeprazole 20 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Pantoprazole 40 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Rabeprazole 20 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Proton pump inhibitor at a dose or frequency other than the options provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.addInfoContent: If esomeprazole is chosen, it can either be given as 40 mg once daily or 20 mg twice daily. The Toronto Consensus guideline considers 20 mg twice daily to be the standard dose for the treatment of H. pylori.

options.label: Tetracycline 500 mg orally four times daily for 14 days (preferred if available)
Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 14 days
Tetracycline-derivative at a dose or frequency other than the options provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)
Bismuth subsalycilate 524 mg orally four times daily for 14 days
Bismuth subsalycilate at a dose or frequency other than the option provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.question: Select metronidazole.
questions.summaryOverview: The drug doses given in this UpToDate Pathway generally represent the doses that are suggested for patients who do not require dose adjustments due to factors such as comorbid illnesses, organ dysfunction, drug interactions, or other reasons. Consult a clinical drug reference, appropriate UpToDate topic reviews, and/or other resources to confirm the appropriate dosing for a given patient. In addition, some of the medications used in this UpToDate Pathway should not be used concurrently with other medications because of drug interactions, so the interacting medication may need to be held during therapy or an alternative antibiotic regimen chosen (refer to UpToDate content for more details on alternative regimens).

options.label: Metronidazole 250 mg orally four times daily for 14 days
Metronidazole at a dose or frequency other than the option provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.question: Choose a testing approach.
questions.summaryOverview: Confirmation of H. pylori eradication can be obtained with a stool or breath test. For patients who are scheduled for an upper endoscopy following treatment, eradication can be determined at the time of endoscopy. Testing should be done at least 4 weeks after treatment is completed. Patients should not take a PPI or bismuth for 4 weeks prior to confirmation testing.

options.label: H. pylori urea breath test
H. pylori stool antigen test
Eradication will be confirmed during upper endoscopy
Refer to gastroenterology for eradicatin confirmation
Refer to infectious disease specialist for eradicatin confirmation
Eradication confirmation using an approach other than options provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.content: Confirmation of H. pylori eradication by stool or breath test following treatment is recommended. (Additional information)
questions.addInfoContent:
Confirmation of H. pylori eradication by stool or breath test following treatment is recommended. For patients who are scheduled for an upper endoscopy following treatment, eradication can be determined at the time of endoscopy. For other patients, an H. pylori test should be done at least 4 weeks after treatment is completed. Patients should not take a PPI or bismuth for 4 weeks prior to confirmation testing.

Note, in patients with peptic ulcers, antisecretory therapy with a PPI may need to be continued for more than 4 weeks (thus delaying eradication confirmation). For patients with complicated duodenal ulcers (eg, ulcers with bleeding, gastric outlet obstruction, ulcer penetration, or perforation), the PPI should be continued for 4 to 8 weeks. For patients with gastric ulcers, the PPI should be continued for 8 to 12 weeks.

options.label: Esomeprazole 40 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Esomeprazole 20 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Lansoprazole 30 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Omeprazole 20 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Pantoprazole 40 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Rabeprazole 20 mg orally once daily for 14 days
Proton pump inhibitor at a dose or frequency other than the options provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.addInfoContent: If esomeprazole is chosen, it can either be given as 40 mg once daily or 20 mg twice daily. The Toronto Consensus guideline considers 20 mg twice daily to be the standard dose for the treatment of H. pylori.

questions.question: Is the patient allergic to penicillin or amoxicillin?
questions.summaryDescription: Patient allergic to penicillin or amoxicillin:

options.label: Yes
No

pathway.statement: Treat with metronidazole-based triple~therapy and confirm eradication

options.label: Order triple therapy with metronidazole, clarithromycin, and a PPI
Approach other than the option provided (this approach may differ from the recommendations of UpToDate)

questions.content:
Triple therapy for 14 days is appropriate for this patient.(Additional information)

Triple therapy for patients who cannot take penicillins includes:
  • A proton pump inhibitor (PPI)
  • Metronidazole
  • Clarithromycin
Choose a treatment approach

For patients who are scheduled for an upper endoscopy following treatment, eradication can be determined at the time of endoscopy. For patients with gastric ulcers, the PPI should be continued for 8 to 12 weeks.

mainTitle: Helicobacter pylori: Initial treatment for adults
